DIMETHYL FUMARATE

  • Indications and doses
  • Drug action
  • Pregnancy
  • Hepatic impairment
  • Renal impairment
  • Side effects
  • Patient and carer advice

  • Medicinal forms

Indications and doses

Treatment of adults with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (initiated by a specialist),

By mouth

  • For adults
    120 mg twice daily for 7 days, then increased to 240 mg twice daily, for dose adjustment due to side effects—consult product literature.

Drug action

Dimethyl fumarate has immunomodulatory and anti-inflammatory properties.

Advice when patient is pregnant

Manufacturer advises avoid unless essential and potential benefit outweighs risk—toxicity in animal studies.

Advice regarding hepatic impairment

Manufacturer advises caution in severe impairment.

Advice regarding renal impairment

Manufacturer advises caution in severe impairment.

Known side effects

General side effects

notKnown: Abdominal pain, burning sensation, diarrhoea, dyspepsia, erythema, flushing (may be severe and indicate hypersensitivity), gastritis, gastroenteritis, leucopenia, lymphopenia, nausea, proteinuria, pruritus, rash, vomiting,

Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML)

Severe prolonged lymphopenia reported, and patients are exposed to a potential risk of PML. Treatment should be stopped immediately if PML is suspected.

Advice for patients and carers

Counselling is advised on progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy.

Patient information leaflet should be provided.

National funding/access decisions

NICE TA320

Dimethyl fumarate for treating relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (August 2014)

Dimethyl fumarate is recommended for the treatment of active relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis, only if:

  • the patient does not have highly active or rapidly evolving severe relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis and
  • the manufacturer provides dimethyl fumarate with the discount agreed in the patient access scheme

Patients currently receiving dimethyl fumarate whose disease does not meet the above criteria should be able to continue treatment until they and their clinician consider it appropriate to stop.

www.nice.org.uk/TA320 www.nice.org.uk/TA320

Cautions regarding administration

  • Reduced lymphocyte count
  • risk of serious infections (do not start treatment until resolved and consider suspending treatment if infection develops during treatment)
  • severe active gastro-intestinal disease

Advice regarding conception and contraception

Contraception required in women of child-bearing potential (consider non-hormonal methods).

Monitoring requirements

Patient parameters

Monitor full blood count (including lymphocytes) before treatment (within 6 months before initiation), then every 6 to 12 months thereafter, and as clinically indicated.

Monitor patient closely for features of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) (e.g. signs and symptoms of neurological dysfunction) and other opportunistic infections.

Monitor renal and hepatic function before treatment, after 3 and 6 months of treatment, then every 6 to 12 months thereafter, and as clinically indicated.

Prepared medicinal forms of DIMETHYL FUMARATE

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.

Gastro-resistant capsule
